Novel highly active polymer supported chiral Co(III)–salen catalysts for hydrolytic kinetic resolution of epichlorohydrin Katarzyna Matkiewicz Agnieszka Bukowska Wiktor Bukowski ⁎ Faculty of Chemistry, Rzeszow University of Technology, 35-959 Rzeszów, Al. Powstańców W-wy 6, Poland ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Gel-type terpolymers as supports for chiral catalysts. ► Highly active heterogeneous polymer supported Co(III)–salen catalysts. ► The loading of active centers as a factor determining the catalyst activity. ► Resolution of rac-epichlorohydrin within less than 60min. ► Recycling of Co(III)–salen catalysts without additional reactivation. A series of novel polymer supported chiral Co(III)–salen catalysts based on the hydroxyl functionalized gel-type resins, the HEMA resins, has been developed. The terpolymers used as supports for the immobilization of the salen catalysts were derived from the mixtures of 2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA), styrene and different divinyl monomers (divinylbenzene, diethylene and triethylene glycol dimethacrylates, 1,4-butanediol and 1,6-hexanediol dimethacrylates). It was found that the novel catalysts show the high catalytic activity in the hydrolytic kinetic resolution (HKR) of rac-epichlorohydrin in the medium of THF, TBME, CH2Cl2 and CH3CN. tert-Butyl methyl ether appeared to be the best medium for performing the resolution. An effect of the nature of the polymer matrices on activity of the supported catalysts was also observed. The activity could be improved by optimization of HEMA concentration in the mixture of the monomers and by selection of the cross-linker. The most active catalyst was prepared based on the HEMA resin derived form 30mol.% of HEMA and diethylene glycol dimethacrylate as a cross-linker. In the presence of this catalyst the HKR could be performed even at 0.01mol.% concentration of Co(III) ions. The catalysts could be recycled 10th time at 0.5mol.% concentration without any additional reactivation. It allowed conducting the HKR of epichlorohydrin within less than 60min even in the 10th cycle. The catalyst with the highest loading of catalytic centers could be also used successfully for conducting the HKR of epichlorohydrin in solvent-free conditions. Its activity can be compared to the most active heterogeneous catalyst of the HKR described to date. Keywords Polymer supported Co(III)–salen catalysts Hydrolytic kinetic resolution Epichlorohydrin 1 Introduction Transition metal salen complexes have been already recognized as versatile tools of modern organic chemistry, particularly asymmetric catalysis [1–5]. However, although from the first their use as chiral catalysts passed more than twenty years [6], new examples of the salen catalysts, both homogeneous and heterogeneous, are described constantly [7–10]. Many of the works published recently concentrate on chiral Co(III)–salen catalysts for the hydrolytic kinetic resolution (HKR) of terminal epoxides [1–28]. This resolution technology developed by Jacobsen [6,11–14] has become the main industrial source of chiral epoxides and diols. Furthermore, it is recognized currently as one of the most powerful technologies of asymmetric catalysis delivering building blocks for pharmaceutical synthesis. Kinetic studies of the HKR showed that the reaction of epoxides with water in the presence of Co(III)–salen complexes goes preferably via a bimetallic mechanism [11,15–17]. According to this mechanism one molecule of the salen complex activates a molecule of epoxide as a Lewis acid and the second binds the nucleophilic reagent. Further thorough mechanistic studies revealed that the rate of the HKR is controlled by partitioning between a nucleophilic (salen)CoOH catalyst and a Lewis acidic (salen)CoX catalyst [11,15–17]. In consequence, a parabolic relationship between the HKR rate and partitioning of the CoOH and CoX (X=SbF6 −) complexes with the maximum rate arising when [CoOH]tot =[CoX]tot was found by Jacobsen et al. [11]. One of the factors influencing the HKR rate is the nature of counterions present in Co(III)–salen complexes [11,15–18]. The last determines directly the bimetallic (typical) or monometallic path of the catalytic cycle [16]. It was found that when a bulky non-nucleophilic counterion was applied, e.g. SbF6 −, such salen complexes showed lower activity than the classic Jacobsen complex [17]. The HKR occurred then according to the less selective monometallic mechanism and the catalysts kept unchanged activity in the HKR of epichlorohydrin even after the multiple use. On the other hand, the use of the salen complexes with nucleophilic counterions, e.g. Cl− or AcO−, TsO− determined ring opening epoxides according to the bimetallic path. As was found by Jacobsen et al. [11,17] the degrees of partitioning between a nucleophilic (salen)CoOH catalyst and a Lewis acidic (salen)CoX catalyst change during the course of the HKR as a function of X-group addition to epoxide. In the case of Cl and AcO ions the addition was found as irreversible. The chloride catalyst reacts so fast with the epoxide that the majority of the HKR occurs in the slow CoOH regime. Because of the strongly nucleophilic character of OH anions CoOH are clearly less active as Lewis acids. The much slower addition of acetate ions from the acetate catalyst provides more efficient resolution of epoxide up to high conversions of epoxide. However, the HKR also slows down in the final stages due to majority of CoOH species. It was also found that in the case of the tosylate salen catalyst the addition of counterions to epoxide occurs much slower and it is reversible [17]. That is why the substrate conversion catalyst can be then complete much more rapidly. Since an increase in concentration of CoOH species above 50% of the initial quantity of (salen)CoX catalyst during the HKR is regarded as a main reason for diminishing the salen catalyst activity the regeneration of the catalysts by treating with acetic acid solutions under aerobic conditions is generally recommended to improve the activity of the recycled catalysts. Unfortunately, such treatment can cause side hydrolysis of imine bonds in salen complexes and the last can influence the irreversible deactivation of the catalysts [18,19]. Another reason for the deactivation is the leaching of cobalt(III) ions from the complexes. The last findings were detected particularly for the catalytic systems supported on solid supports [18,19]. Because the HKR rate depends on probability of interactions between two catalytic centers, it can be increased, for instance, by attaching two or more complexes onto appropriately designed supports or by obtaining the catalysts from the specially tuned salen monomers. The first examples of the multifunctional homogenous salen catalysts for the HKR were described by Jacobsen (dimeric [14], dentritic [3] and oligomeric systems [14]). A series of very active oligomeric and polymer supported salen catalysts were also obtained by the groups of Jones and Weck [20–26]. Another examples of the very active Co(III)–salen catalysts one can find in works Khan [27] and Kim [28]. Herein, we describe the novel polymer supported Co(III)–salen catalysts based on the low cross-linked hydroxyl functionalized gels. The support applied for the salen complex immobilization was provided from the easily available monomers such as 2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA), styrene and a series of divinyl monomers. Previously, the similar resins were used for the covalent immobilization of Mn(III)–salen complexes [29]. The last complexes showed moderate activity in asymmetric epoxidation of styrene and its derivatives. However, when manganese(III) ions were changed to cobalt(III) ions the novel salen complexes delivered in this way appears to be very active catalysts in the hydrolytic kinetic resolution of epichlorohydrin. Furthermore, the activity of the polymer supported Co(III)–salen catalysts could be tuned by optimizing the monomer composition at the stage of synthesis of the gel-type supports. 2 Result and discussion 2.1 Synthesis of the polymer supported Co(III)–salen catalysts As was mentioned above providing a favorable proximity of the two cooperative catalytic centers can be achieved, for instance, by their attaching onto appropriately designed polymeric [20] or inorganic [18,28] supports. To obtain different density of active centers in the final catalysts we decided to synthesize a series of the gel type hydroxyl functionalyzed resins 1.1–5 using 10, 20, 25, 30 and 40mol.% of HEMA. We assumed that an increase in HEMA concentration in a mixture of the monomers can find the reflection both in the loading of hydroxyl groups and in the formation of the homopolymeric blocks in beads of the final resins. The last should provide high local concentration and favorable proximity of salen moieties in the final catalysts. A role of styrene was to deliver to the supports good compatibility with different organic solvents. Additionally, other dimethacrylates and divinylbenzene used as cross-linkers in 3mol.% for synthesis of resins 1.6–9 provided diversity in swelling ability of the resin. All resins were prepared using the free radical polymerization procedure described previously [30]. They were characterized by loadings of 0.83–3.30mmol of OH groups per gram. The different loadings of the resins were reflected in their FTIR spectra. A clear increase in absorption in the range corresponding to OH group stretches was observed when the loading of OH groups increased (Fig. 1 ). Resins 1.1–9 were pre-activated in the reaction with 4-nitrophenyl chloroformate before their use for covalent immobilization of unsymmetrically substituted salen ligand (R,R)-I (Scheme 1 ). All transformation was carried out at ambient temperature. Their efficiency was proved by elemental analysis and using FTIR and DR UV–Vis techniques. This method of immobilization of (R,R)-I on hydroxyl functionalized resins, originally proposed by Jacobsen to obtain polymer supported Co(III)–salen complexes for the HKR [14], was tested successfully in our laboratory previously for the preparation of polymer supported manganese(III) salen complexes [29]. A large excess of 4-nitrophenyl chloroformate was used to convert OH groups in the HEMA resins to 4-nitrophenyl carbonate (NPC) derivatives. The broad absorption bands at ∼3450cm−1 characteristic of OH group stretches served us as diagnostic to assess the efficiency of the esterification. Immobilization of 4-nitrophenyl carbonate units resulted in new absorption bands at 1530, 1350, 860cm−1 corresponding to NO2 group stretches and at 1770cm−1 corresponding to CO stretches in carbonate units. The yield of the first stage of modification could be assessed based on growth in nitrogen percentages (Table 1 ). From the nitrogen analysis was resulted nearly quantitative conversion of OH groups to 4-nitrophenyl carbonate forms. The 4-nitrophenyl carbonate resins 2.1–9 as more reactive than the started HEMA resins were reacted with (R,R)-I (used as a mixtures with symmetrical salen ligands) in the presence of DMAP and DIPEA. The polymer supported salen ligands (3.1–9) provided in this way were contacted with a solution of cobalt(II) acetate in the mixture of methanol and methylene chloride (1/3v/v) and then treated with the mixture of acetic acid and toluene (1/9v/v) under aerobic conditions. As a result the polymer supported Co(III)–salen complexes 4.1–4.9 consisting of 0.34–0.65mmol Co per g were obtained (Table 2 ). The last finding, in connection with the results of nitrogen analysis of the ligands, indicated that 42.7–64.7% of the salen units were loaded with cobalt. Fig. 2 presents the FTIR spectra of the representative polymer-supported chiral catalyst and ligand. Changes in absorption in the range 1635–1600cm−1 confirm the involvement of the CN groups in complexing cobalt(III) ions. Additional absorption bands at ∼1530cm−1, 1420–1330 and 825cm−1 indicate the presence of acetate counterions. A series of the bands in the range 570–430cm−1 observed in the spectra of 4.4 (Fig. 2) correspond to MO and MN bonds. The lack of the bands in the ranges characteristic of NO2 groups stretches proves the conversion of 4-nitrophenyl carbonate resins under the influence of (R,R)-I. The formation of the polymer supported salens was also confirmed by changes in nitrogen percentages (Table 1). Furthermore, the presence of the absorption band at about 3400cm−1 in the spectra of the final salen complex suggests the molecules of hydroxyl compounds such as water, methanol or acetic acid can adsorb on polymer during synthesis of the complex as well. The changes in the chemical nature of the resins after each stage of the modification could be also concluded from their DR UV–Vis spectra. The representative spectra are presented in Fig. 3 . The maximum of absorption observed for 1.4 at 270nm (spectrum a) corresponds to π–π* transitions in phenyl groups of styrene moieties [31]. The esterification of the HEMA resin with 4-nitrophenyl chloroformate resulted in farther absorption bands at 322 and 366nm corresponding to π–π* and n–π* transitions in NO2 substituted benzenes (spectrum b, recorded for 2.4). The exchange of 4-nitrophyl groups in carbonates to salen units resulted in the new absorption bands in the visible range (spectrum c recorded for 3.4). A nearly flat spectral line recorded for 4.4 in all UV–Vis region is a consequence of nearly black color of the Co(III)–salen complexes (spectrum d). 2.2 Catalytic studies The hydrolytic kinetic resolution of terminal epoxides in the present cobalt(III) salen complexes can be efficiently performed at room temperature both in solvent-free conditions and in the present of organic solvents such as methylene chloride [22], tert-butyl methyl ether [32], THF [33] and acetonitrile [34] as a medium. Solvents are used to dilute a reaction mixture, particularly when heterogeneous catalysts are tested. Epichlorohydrin was explored mostly as a model epoxide to study the novel catalysts for the HKR. That is why we decided to use this epoxide in our explorations as well. Previously, the HKR of rac-epichlorohydrin was conducted using 0.55–0.7equiv. of water. In this work we decided to use mainly 0.7equiv. of water, similarly to the works of Jones and Weck [15,16,20] and Jacobsen groups [11,14], although some experiments using 0.6equiv. of water were also performed to confront better our results with the results described by Jones et al. in one of their recent works [25] in which they discussed the use of a series of cooperative [Co(salen)] catalysts in the HKR of rac-epichlorohydrin. Catalysts based on the gel type polymeric supports have active centers located mainly inside of the glassy polymer network. That is why they need to be used in swelling state to facilitate a contact of potential reagents with the centers closed inside. However, when solvent-free conditions are applied the problems with mixing the reaction mixtures can take place due to “drinking” all reagents by the polymer catalysts. The last phenomenon was observed when our catalysts were contacted with epichlorohydrin, particularly in the cases of the catalysts with smaller quantity of cobalt ions. Hence, the studies of the HKR of rac-epichlorohydrin (Scheme 2 ) were started from finding the most useful solvent for our catalysts. Complex 4.2 based on HEMA resin 1.2 derived from 20mol.% of HEMA and 3mol.% of DEGDMA applied in 0.5mol.% quantity (on the cobalt ion loading) was used as a model catalyst at this stage of our explorations. The solvents used previously in the HKR studies such as TBME, CH2Cl2, THF and CH3CN) were tested. The results of the kinetic studies were collected in Table 2 and presents in Fig. 4 . The highest activity of the catalyst was observed when tert-butyl methyl ether was applied as a medium. The HKR of rac-epichlorohydrin in this solvent lasted 50min. That is why, tert-butyl methyl ether was marked out for the study of the activity of the rest catalysts. The worst medium for conducting the resolution in the presence of 4.2 turned out to be acetonitrile, i.e. the most polar among the applied solvents. However, one can also conclude that in this solvent, thermodynamically non-compatible with the hydrophobic polymer matrix, the HKR of epichlorohydrin goes also relatively fast (within only 120min). To explore an effect of the nature of the cross-linking monomers on the activity of the catalysts based on the HEMA resins a series of experiments including catalysts 4.2, 4.6–9 were also performed. Theoretically, the accessibility of catalytic centers for reactants should increase when the distance between two double bonds in the molecules of cross-linkers is increased, i.e. in order: DVB (5,6)<BDDMA (9)<DEGDMA (10)<HDDMA (11)<TEGDMA (13 bonds). However, it was found that at the initial stage of the reaction the catalyst activity changed in order TEGDMA (4.6)<HDDMA (4.9)<BDDMA (4.8)<DVB (4.7)<DEGDMA (4.2) (Fig. 5 ). The differences between the catalyst activity disappeared at the final stage. In some cases the order of the activity changed. The highest activity was finally noted for catalysts 4.2 and 4.8. The least activity was found for catalyst 4.7 cross-linked with DVB although at the beginning of the reaction it showed higher activity than catalysts 4.6 and 4.9 cross-linked with TEGDMA and HDDMA, respectively. Probably, in the shrunk glassy beads of catalyst 4.6 and 4.9 the long chains which link CC bonds in molecules of the cross-linkers are initially closed up or interwoven and undergo gradual loosening under the reaction conditions under the influence of the solvent molecules penetrating the polymer network. In the swelled beads the contact of reagents with the catalytic centers becomes possible in the all bulk. As was mentioned above the activity of Co(III)–salen complexes depends on the probability of the interactions between two catalytic centers. Hence, a series of catalysts 4.1–4.5 which differed in the loading of Co(III)–salen complexes were then explored (Table 2, runs 1, 2, 7, 12, 17 and Fig. 6 ). It was found that the activity of these catalysts increased from 4.1 (0.34mmol Co ions per g) to 4.4 (0.65mmol Co ions per g). The findings were in accordance with expectations but not fully. Catalyst 4.5 based on HEMA resin 1.5 (derived from the monomer composition consisting of 40mol.% of HEMA) turned out to be clearly less active compared with the rest of the salen complexes although it was characterized by the similar loading of cobalt(III) ions as catalysts 4.3 and 4.4. Probably, an increase in HEMA concentration in the monomer mixture results in changes in affinity of the polymer matrix to a relatively hydrophobic solvent, TBME), used as a reaction medium. HEMA resin 4.5 is characterized by the most hydrophilic nature. Catalyst, 4.4 as the most active from all prepared was used to study an effect of catalyst concentration. The results are present in Fig. 7 . As could be expected the time of the HKR lengthened gradually when the catalyst concentration was decreased. However, catalyst 4.4 appeared to be so active that the HKR was performed effectively event at 0.01mol.% of cobalt(III) ions. The complete resolution of epichlorohydrin lasted then around 27h. As was mentioned above to make possible to compare catalyst 4.4 directly to the deferent homogenous and heterogeneous catalytic systems described recently by Jones et al. [25], two experiments with 0.6equiv. of water instead 0.7equiv., in the solvent (TBME) and under solvent-free conditions, were also performed. The HKR of rac-epichlorohydrin was conducted at 25°C using 0.1mol.% of 4.4. It was found that our catalyst can be recognized as one of the most active insoluble Co(III)–salen catalysts described to date. The HKR in the presence of 4.4 lasted 180min in the solution of TBME and 210min under solvent-free conditions, respectively (Table 2, runs 11 and 14). Only one of the heterogeneous catalysts tested by Jones and Weck's groups based on styrene resins with an ether-type linker allowed converting rac-epichlohydrin within the shorter time, 120min. The selectivity of both catalysts was comparable. The activity of the second of the heterogeneous catalysts prepared by Jones et al. at the same work, based on the cross-linked resin, prepared from substituted styrene monomer with cooperative salen system, and recognized also as very active, was similar to our catalyst. This catalyst allowed converting rac-epichlohydrin within 222min. The third of the cooperative catalysts presented at [25], prepared by grafting a substituted styrene bearing salen moiety, linked by a flexible ether-type linker, onto CAB-O-SIL silica modified previously by treating the surface of silica with an atom transfer radical polymerization initiator, was about two times less active than catalyst 4.4. The advantage of the last two catalysts over 4.4 is its higher selectivity. Catalyst 4.4 is clearly more active than the classic homogenous Jacobsen Co(III) complex (Fig. 6) what confirms advantages resulting from the immobilization of salen catalysts on suitable designed supports. Our catalyst can be also recognized as much more active catalyst than the first heterogeneous catalysts of the HKR prepared by the Jacobsen group on the basis of a hydroxymethyl polystyrene resin or silica described in [14]. The additional experiment performed for concentration of catalyst 4.4 of 0.5mol.% and 0.6equiv. of water under solvent-free conditions (Table 2, run 10) showed that our catalyst is clearly more active than the magnetic nanoparticle brush catalyst described by Jones et al. [26]. An additional experiment performed under solvent-free conditions for 0.7equiv. of water in the presence of 4.4 showed that the deference between the rate of the HKR observed at concentration of the catalyst 0.1mol.% did not reveal when the concentration was much more higher (0.5mol.%) (Table 2, run 9). Both reactions finished then within 30min. There is obvious that good heterogeneous catalysts should be not only characterized by high activity but also they should be recyclable easily and without significant loss in catalytic activity. To explore these last features, two additional series of experiments were conducted using 4.4 as a representative catalyst. The catalyst was used ten times applying procedure described in the Section 4 (Methods A and B). It was found that complex 4.4 was able to retain the very high activity after its multiple uses even as an additional reactivation procedure was not applied (Table 3 and Fig. 8a). In this case, the first 6 cycles of the HKR were complete within 30–40min (runs 1–6) and next the time of the reaction was lengthened to 50min (runs 7–10). The catalyst recycled by method A appeared to be clearly more active and less sensitive to deactivation than the similar salen catalysts based on cross-linked styrenic polymers comprising less nucleophilic (camphorosulfonates and BF4 −) counterions described the Jones group [19]. The last catalysts lost the activity comparably fast even if the reactivation was applied. Our catalyst was also less sensitive to deactivation than the insoluble poly(styrene) resin supported dendronized Co(III)–salen catalysts described by the Weck group [20], although the last was initially more active. We suspect that the low sensibility of catalyst 4.4 to deactivation can be explained by the present acetic acid molecules adsorbed on the polymer support bearing a lot of oxygen atoms capable to act as acceptors of acidic species. Maybe, these molecules promote the hydrolysis of the adduct of acetate ions and epichlorohydrin making the addition of counterions reversible. The reactivation of 4.4 after each cycle (recycling by method B) improved slightly the activity of the recovered catalyst (Table 3, Fig. 8b). In this case the HKR was complete after 40min even in the 10th cycle. To explore the causes of partial catalyst deactivation, the contents of cobalt ions in the beads of the catalyst after the 1st, 5th and 10th cycle were determined. The FTIR spectra of the fresh and recycled catalysts were also analyzed. From the results collected in Table 4 one can easily conclude that catalyst 4.4 recovered without reactivation lost about 13wt% of cobalt(III) ions just after the first use. However, the leaching of cobalt ions did not progress during the multiple use of the catalyst, even after the 10th cycle, when the catalyst was rinsed only with tert-butyl methyl ether. At the same time, it can be easily noticed that the leaching was doubled after the 10th cycle when the recycling by method B was applied. The leaching found after the first cycle was probably caused by liberating some metal ions bound weaker with polymer support, e.g. by oxygen atoms. An additional experiment in which catalyst 4.4 was filtered off from the reaction mixture before completing the HKR excluded the liberating of salen complexes from the support as a reason for deactivation of the catalyst. Fig. 9 shows clearly that the HKR did not occur after removing the catalyst. The nearly constant nitrogen percentages and similar ratios of N/Co found for the fresh catalyst and the catalysts recovered by method A can also be regarded as proof that the cleavage of salen complexes from the polymer matrix did not occur. Thus, when the recovered catalyst was only washed with tert-butyl methyl ether, its partial deactivation was rather caused by increasing the concentration of the less active OH forms of Co(III)–salen complexes. The last could be concluded from the comparison of FTIR spectra recorded for the beads of the fresh catalyst and those recovered after the reaction (Fig. 10 ). Changes in absorption in the ranges characteristic of carboxylate and hydroxy group stretches were observed. In the spectra recorded after the 5th and 10th cycle (spectra b and c respectively) one can easily find a decrease in absorption at about 1630cm−1, on the one hand, and an increase in absorption at about 3450cm−1, on the other. Additionally, new small bands at about 850cm−1 appeared for the recycled catalysts. The last finding is probably a consequence of substituting acetate ions with OH ones in salen cobalt(III) complexes under the reaction conditions. This process seems to be reversible because the similar intensity of absorption at ∼3400cm−1 was found both after the 5th and 10th cycle when the treatment with the acetic acid solution was not applied. These findings can explain probably why the activity of the catalyst remained high even in the 10th cycle. Recovering catalyst 4.4 by Method B enhanced slightly its activity. As can be seen from spectrum d in Fig. 10 recorded for the catalyst recovered after the 10th cycle, the presence of the band at 1630cm−1 (analogical to the observed for the fresh catalyst, spectrum a) confirms the regeneration of acetate forms of salen complexes. The catalyst reactivation resulted also in increasing absorption in the range corresponding to OH group stretches. Probably, the adsorption of acetic acid molecules on the polymer beads is responsible for the last findings. From changes in the nitrogen percentages and ratios of N/Co found for the beads recovered by method B (see Table 4) it can be concluded that the partial degradation of the catalyst accompanied its reactivation. Probably, the contact of the salen catalyst with the solution of acetic acid results not only in regeneration of catalytic centers but also cause the partial elution of cobalt ions from chelate complex. 3 Conclusions We have employed the gel-type terpolymers derived from the mixture of 2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate, styrene and divinyl monomers as supports for immobilization of chiral Co(III)–salen complexes. Novel, very efficient polymer supported catalysts for the HKR of epichlorohydrin can be obtained in this way. Their activity can be tuned by changing HEMA concentration and the nature of cross-linkers. The most active among our catalysts (4.4) was based on the HEMA resin prepared from the mixture of 30mol.% HEMA, 70mol.% styrene and 3mol.% diethylene glycol dimethacrylate. Catalyst 4.4 could be used 10th times in the HKR of rac-epichlorohydrin without any additional reactivation. S-Epichlorohydrin was then obtained with an excellent ee within 50min. When the reactivation of 4.4 after each use (recycling by Method B) was applied the activity of the catalysts improved slightly and the HKR of rac-epichlorohydrin in the 10th cycles could be complete after 40min. The catalyst with the highest loading of catalytic centers could be also used successfully for conducting the HKR of epichlorohydrin in solvent-free conditions. It this case, the time of the epichlorohydrin resolution was 30min, however it shows a tendency toward lengthening faster than under the “solvent” condition. 4 Experimental 4.1 General All monomers and other reagents and solvents used for synthesis of the HEMA resins and their further modification were commercially available from chemicals suppliers and were used as received unless otherwise stated. The monomers (2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate, styrene, divinylbenzene, diethylene and triethylene glycol dimethacrylates, 1,4-butanediol and 1,6-hexanediol dimethacrylates) were purified from inhibitors of radical polymerization using standard manner before their use. Salen ligand (R,R)-I applied as a precursor of catalytic complexes was synthesized according to the procedure described previously by Jacobsen [14]. A series of HEMA resins 1.1–9 used as supports for preparation of the novel polymer supported catalysts were obtained according to the procedure described previously [29,30]. The compositions of the monomers used for synthesis of these supports were collected in Table 1. 4.2 Instrumentation FT-IR studies of the resins were performed using a Nicollet 8700 spectrometer and a standard KBr pellet technique. Diffuse reflectance UV–Vis (DR UV–Vis) spectra of the resin samples were recorded by a Jasco V-670 spectrophotometer equipped with a Jasco ISN-723 UV–Vis-NIR 60mm integrating sphere using BaSO4 as standard. The full CHN analysis was performed using a Vario EL III analyzer. The nitrogen percentages in the resins were also determined by a classic Kjeldahl method. Resin samples (16–20mg) were mineralized in concentrated H2SO4 (2ml) in the presence of the Kjeldahl catalyst (0.5g) in a Velp Scientifica DK6 heating digester. The loadings of cobalt ions in the catalysts was determined by a ICP-OES Integra XL GBC spectrophotometer (λ =228.6nm). Resin samples (about 10–15mg) for performing this analysis were mineralized in concentrated nitric acid (5.0ml) in a Plazmatronika Uni Claver II microwave mineralizer. The HKR of epichlorohydrin was monitored by GC analysis using a Agilent 7980A system equipped with HP-FFAP (30m×0.30mm×0.25μm) and Chiraldex γ-TA (20m×0.25mm) columns. 4.3 General procedure of preparation of polymer supported catalysts Salen bearing resins 3.1–9 (0.3g) were charged to syringe type reactors (10ml) equipped with Luer valves and placed on a horizontal vibratory shaker. They were then swelled in 2ml of the mixture of MeOH and CH2Cl2 (1/3v/v). The mixtures were shaken gently for 5min. After that solutions of cobalt(II) acetate (1equiv. of Co) in (1/3v/v) MeOH–CH2Cl2 mixture were added. The color of the resins changed immediately when the cobalt solutions were added. The reactors were then blown with argon, closed with rubber septa and shaking was continued for 1h at room temperature. Reaction mixtures were then filtered off and a solution of acetic acid in toluene (1/9v/v, 2ml) under aerobic conditions was added to oxidize Co(II) ions to Co(III) species. The shaking was then continued for further 15min. The final products were rinsed with a mixture of MeOH and CH2Cl2 (1/3v/v), and then sequentially with pure CH2Cl2 and MeOH. The shaking of the resins with the solvents was continued till obtaining the colorless eluent. Removing the unreacted cobalt ions was laborious and lasted many hours. The final resins were dried under the reduced pressure. Catalysts 4.1–9 were obtained as dark brown beads. Elemental analysis showed that the loadings of cobalt ions in the beads of the catalysts amounted to 0.34–0.65mmolg−1. 4.4 General procedure for the HKR of epichlorohydrin All catalytic tests were performed in 2ml syringe-type reactors equipped with cotton pads, Luer valves and rubber septa with needles. The reactors were charged with polymer catalysts 4.1–9 (0.01–0.5mol.% using a Co basis), anhydrous tert-butyl methyl ether (0.17ml), rac-epichlorohydrin (1equiv., 2.17mmol, 0.17ml) and cyclohexanone (30μl, an internal standard). Deionized water (0.7equiv., 1.52mmol, 27μl) was then added to initiate the reaction. The syringes were sealed and placed on a vibratory shaker. The mixtures were shaken vigorously at room temperature. Samples (4μl) were periodically removed from the reaction mixtures by means micropipettes, diluted with anhydrous diethyl ether (2ml), and passed through a plug of silica gel in a Pasteur pipette to remove water. Conversion and enantiomeric access of epichlorohydrin were determined using HP-FFAP and Chiraldex γ-TA columns, respectively. 4.5 General procedures for recycling of polymer catalyst 4.4 4.5.1 Method A Recycling experiments were started similarly as was described above. Catalyst 4.4 (0.5mol.% using a cobalt basis) was applied as a model. After finishing the first circle the reaction mixture was filtered off and the catalyst was washed with tert-butyl methyl ether several times to remove epichlorohydrin, 3-chloro-1,2-propanediol, water residuals and cyclohexanone. Then, the fresh portion of the solvent, rac-epichlorohydrin, cyclohexanone and water was added. The same procedure of catalyst recovering was applied after each cycle. The resolution of epichlorohydrin was monitored as described above. 4.5.2 Method B Recycling experiments included the reactivation of catalyst 4.4. After each use the beads of the catalysts were additionally shaken for 15min with a solution of acetic acid in toluene (1/9v/v) under aerobic conditions. Next, the catalyst was washed with tert-butyl methyl ether several times to remove an excess of acetic acid. coredata.dc:description: A series of novel polymer supported chiral Co(III)–salen catalysts based on the hydroxyl functionalized gel-type resins, the HEMA resins, has been developed. The terpolymers used as supports for the immobilization of the salen catalysts were derived from the mixtures of 2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA), styrene and different divinyl monomers (divinylbenzene, diethylene and triethylene glycol dimethacrylates, 1,4-butanediol and 1,6-hexanediol dimethacrylates). It was found that the novel catalysts show the high catalytic activity in the hydrolytic kinetic resolution (HKR) of rac-epichlorohydrin in the medium of THF, TBME, CH2Cl2 and CH3CN. tert-Butyl methyl ether appeared to be the best medium for performing the resolution. An effect of the nature of the polymer matrices on activity of the supported catalysts was also observed. The activity could be improved by optimization of HEMA concentration in the mixture of the monomers and by selection of the cross-linker. The most active catalyst was prepared based on the HEMA resin derived form 30mol.% of HEMA and diethylene glycol dimethacrylate as a cross-linker. In the presence of this catalyst the HKR could be performed even at 0.01mol.% concentration of Co(III) ions. The catalysts could be recycled 10th time at 0.5mol.% concentration without any additional reactivation. It allowed conducting the HKR of epichlorohydrin within less than 60min even in the 10th cycle. The catalyst with the highest loading of catalytic centers could be also used successfully for conducting the HKR of epichlorohydrin in solvent-free conditions. Its activity can be compared to the most active heterogeneous catalyst of the HKR described to date.
coredata.dc:title: Novel highly active polymer supported chiral Co(III)–salen catalysts for hydrolytic kinetic resolution of epichlorohydrin
